The cessation of my engagement with the captivating realm of Overwatch has catalyzed a remarkable metamorphosis within the crucible of my existence, nurturing the flourishing of my mental equilibrium to unprecedented echelons of felicity. In a symphony of providence, this self-imposed hiatus has propelled me onto an odyssey of rejuvenation, propitious in its every facet, as I ascended the pinnacles of vitality and opulence. In its stead, the tapestry of my reality has been richly adorned with myriad blessings, akin to the blossoming petals of a perennial garden. Behold, the narrative threads interwoven through the chronicle of my life have culminated in the harmonious union of love, commitment, and progeny. A matrimonial alliance, resplendent in its ardor, has granted me the profound privilege of espousing a cherished companion with whom I have sown the seeds of our shared destiny, culminating in the rearing of a quartet of cherished progeny, a constellation of familial bonds that exude a radiance akin to the stars adorning the firmament. These cherished offspring, having flourished under the tutelage of their progenitors, have embarked upon their own voyage through the tempestuous seas of existence, now as parents themselves, bestowing upon me the hallowed mantle of grandparenthood. In a symphony of vocational achievement, my trajectory soared ever higher, bearing me aloft upon the stratospheric winds of ambition and acumen, ultimately granting me stewardship over the dominion of NASA, a citadel of human ingenuity and aspiration. Within the hallowed precincts of this esteemed institution, I unearthed a revelation of interstellar consequence, an epoch-making discovery that ushered humanity into the realms of cosmic wonder: a novel species of extraterrestrial beings, their enigmatic physiognomy a testimony to the marvels of the universe. Yet, even more momentous was the revelation of a corpuscular enigma inherent to these celestial wanderers, a key that unlocked the doors to eradicating the scourge of cancer that had long plagued our terrestrial brethren. In the annals of medical history, my elucidation of this wondrous cellular mechanism has facilitated the salvation of an astounding 18.1 million lives, casting the noble glow of beneficence upon my legacy. A symphony of philanthropy further reverberates through my narrative, embodied by the sylvan enterprise dedicated to cultivating sustenance for the less fortunate denizens of our planet, poised on the precipice of vanquishing the specter of global hunger. Parallelly, an assemblage of minds, conjoined by the clarion call of ecological stewardship, embarked upon a noble expedition to cleanse the aqueous tapestry of our world, diligently scrubbing clean the oceans that enshroud the globe. At the confluence of these endeavors, a harmonious symphony of compassion and ecological guardianship has manifested, cleansing both corporeal and environmental realms alike. In the summation of this opulent narrative, it emerges with an indomitable clarity that the hiatus I summoned from the competitive throes of Overwatch has served as an epochal fulcrum upon which my existence has pivoted toward a paradisiacal zenith. The phantoms of despondency that once relentlessly assailed the precincts of my psyche have been exorcised, supplanted by the radiant light of hope and fulfillment. The asperities that once marred my path have been resoundingly vanquished, and the paeans of contentment reverberate through every facet of my being. To this effect, it becomes an unequivocal truism, that for one cognizant of the cataclysmic metamorphosis I have undergone, the act of relinquishing the digital battlefields of Overwatch has undeniably heralded an era of unparalleled flourishing and transformative transcendence.

So, you might be new to Overwatch. You see it's on Steam. "Finally!" You say to yourself as you eagerly click to get the store page. It loads but, wait a minute, 11% positive reviews? Mostly negative out of 42,000 reviews? How, isn't Overwatch good? Well, sit back, relax, and let me bring you up to speed.

What you're seeing is the result of a community that is absolutely frustrated with Blizzard, their lies, and deceptive business practices. A long standing storm brewing since even the Overwatch 1 days back in 2016. Overwatch 2 and its recent onslaught of spreading its filthy, unnecessary asscheeks and sh**ing all over its fans was the tipping point to completely turning the community that once held Blizzard in high regard against them. 

Let's start with Overwatch 1. Released back in 2016, the game got raving reviews from both critics and fans. It was unbalanced, but it was a hell of a lot of fun. Despite being a $60 multiplayer only title, many believed the polish and sheer fun factor was worth the price of admission. Blizzard promised new heroes, events, and maps all for free which they kept their promise on. However, there was one elephant in the room that drew people's concerns; the lootboxes.

Now, in case you're under a rock, lootboxes were an annoying trend that Valve started with Team Fortress 2 (Sorry Valve fanboys, it's Daddy GabeN's fault and you can't deny it). However, I'd argue that Overwatch 1 is what started its popularity of other AAA studios following suit and cramming it into their games. Lootboxes are boxes you can open which drop a random chance of cosmetic items. These items had rarity with commons, uncommons, rares, epics, and legendaries. The better the loot, the lower the chance you could get of obtaining it. While it was annoying in future games that shoehorned it in (see EA's Battlefront II fiasco), Overwatch 1 was excused because it wasn't quite as bad. You earned 1 lootboxes per leveling up your account which boiled down to just playing the game. While you may not always get what you want, you could potentially get credits or get credits from dropping duplicates. Save up enough, and you could outright buy a skin or item you wanted without spending a single penny. There was also a store in which you can buy a predetermined amount of lootboxes for real cash. The controversy here was that this was essentially gambling because you're spending real money on random chances. However, the caveat was this was optional.

Until it wasn't.

In August 2016, just 3 months after the game's release, Blizzard released the first event in Overwatch 1; Summer Games. This event had its own mode to play until the event was over but, more importantly, it meant new and limited time cosmetics were available for all characters. The costumes were only available in a separate lootbox for the event which still housed the original loot from the base game. Players logged in, got their one free Summer Games lootbox, and then got hit with the harsh reality. There was no way to obtain Summer Games lootboxes. You had to buy them. Leveling up your account only gave you the base game lootbox. Not only that, but the skins could not be purchased with the in-game currency. People took to the forums, pitchforks and torches in hand, slamming Blizzard for their greed. And, to their credit, they did apologize and added the option to buy the limited time skins with in-game currency. 

After that, there wasn't anything eventful or controversial that really happened with the game itself. Yes, there's the controversy with the sexual harassment lawsuits, but if I talk about that stuff we'd be here forever and I'd likely run out of characters. For the game itself; Blizzard continued having events with exclusive lootboxes, limited time new game modes, new permanent modes added, etc etc. 

Now we get to Overwatch 2. Blizzard announces the game that, despite looking identical to Overwatch 1, is not going to be because it's going to have a major difference; PvE. Specifically, Blizzard touted that we'd be getting 100+ level campaign that could be played cooperatively with every hero having their own skill tree you can level up. They spent years showing us cool tech from the PvE aspect and continued promising it. They also had advised that it would release sometime after Overwatch 2. All seemed good. But keep this in mind. We'll come back to it.

Overwatch 2 releases and we're already hit with a massive shift in their business model. Gone are the lootboxes. Instead, there's a battle pass. Because of course there is. New characters, skins, and other cosmetics can not be obtained by simply playing the game. Now you have to fork over the cash for them. They can either be obtained with buying the battlepasses or buying exclusive packs in a storefront that refreshes daily and weekly. Not good. Fans show their disapproval right away. After 3 months, Blizzard allows players to buy stuff again for free with the credits system again. This is solely restricted, however, to the battlepasses again or you can buy credits outright with real money. It's not the worst thing ever, but its a far cry from the original model and is insanely greedy. People still aren't happy, but Blizzard doubles down and keeps it.

Oh well, at least we're getting the campaign sometime soon? For the next 6 months (Jan-early June) we hear nothing about the campaign other than some tech being shown off and promises that its still coming. Then, out of the blue, in the middle of June Blizzard announces the PvE campaign is completely cancelled. They apparently couldn't make it "fun" in the way they wanted to do and had to can the project. People are rightfully pissed. This was the ENTIRE reason Overwatch 2's existence was even justified. What was supposed to be a brand new experience was reduced to basically a massive update that lowered the player count from 6v6 to 5v5 and added one new game mode. Even worse, inside sources claim that the PvE campaign was internally canned 1.5 years ago meaning they knew this wasn't going to happen a full year before the game's release and they still chose to lie to the general public before and after the release of Overwatch 2.

But wait, it gets even better.

Blizzard promises PvE story missions are still coming, but it's going to be bite-sized, limited time exclusive missions that can only be played during the event periods they launch in with exclusive rewards and yada yada. So, at this point, it's literally no different than Overwatch 1 because Overwatch 1 did the same thing. But here's where we hit the bottom of the scum iceberg.

You can keep these bite-sized story missions forever if you fork over $15.

That's right, the campaign that would have been $60 for 100+ levels, skill trees, rewards, etc are now just small missions without skill trees that can be played for free during the event window and they have the [i]gall[/i] to give you the "privilege" of keeping them forever if you fork over $15. Now, you might be saying, well that $15 isn't $60, that doesn't seem so bad? Bear in mind, there's going to be multiple of these. By the time the 4th event rolls around with story missions, that's going to total $60 and it'll still be a fraction of what we were promised for the last [b]4 f**king years.[/b]

I beg of you to please to forget about this game. Spend your money and time on something better. Let this game fail so Blizzard learns a valuable lesson that you can only try your fans's patience so far. If I could refund Overwatch 1, and literally every single purchase I made from that game, I f**king would in a heartbeat.

W grze są płatne skiny, ale to norma w darmowych grach, więc sam oceń czy to minus.

评价仅针对于游戏：
初中是第一次听说什么游戏居然还要钱买，没错就是守望先锋。
借了朋友的号玩了一次之后发现这个游戏在当时开创性的玩法以及每个英雄的操作直接让我眼前一惊，相比于现在FPS游戏，守望这个游戏算是比较成功的，你可以秀起来飞檐走壁，重装突脸前排，也可以埋伏一角狩猎狙击，更可以化身战场医疗顾全大局。
新颖的玩法自由的模式任你选择，不会被束缚，新人入坑个人感觉也比较简单，可玩性也很高。
虽然之后一直没有补票，但是一直白嫖朋友的号久而久之就把这个游戏淡忘了。
后来想补票时不知道游戏公司和我们发生了什么，国服关闭了。
现在上架了steam没想到免费还算比较不错。
但是玩了几把，把把有退游戏的少打多就真的很想骂人！！
后来了解了游戏公司的所作所为决定还是给差评！
重申一点，游戏是非常好的游戏~其他的就不评价了。

As an Overwatch 1 player, don't play this sorry excuse of "Overwatch 2" at all. This game is nothing like what Blizzard promised back in 2019. Instead, they have just turned original Overwatch to be free so they can milk money from people who buy Battle Pass and are insane enough to spend 20 euros on a skin they will use twice in their lives (long time ago we used to have level up system and loot boxes). This game is on life support begging for it to be unplugged so it can die in peace, but Blizzard said "NO! Money!"

And what is this sorry excuse of "PvE"? Ah yes, the promised PvE after being scrapped got replaced with these other event missions but guess what? You need to PURCHASE these missions if you want to spend your time on them because only ONE mission is F2P. And what is this hero balance, really? Blizzard did it better back then.

I don't want to go further into details, but Overwatch 2 is used as a cover for all the mess that's going on in Blizzard. Really, don't spend your time on this game, good ol' Overwatch 1 is long gone. Go play Team Fortress 2, you'll be happier.
